Posts.Content: Oct 30, 2010 10:23PM orchidgal wrote: p.s. Re: mammograms "saving your life" I've had them since I was 30, and am now 55, and they didn't do anything for me, except cost a lot of time, money and painful procedures. I felt some thickness in early '09 and my dr. sent me for a mammo & ultrasound. Report came back reading: "numerous microcalcifications, dense breasts, difficult to read, presumably benign." One year later the thickening had progressed, and that's when they decided to do a stereotactic core needle biopsy and discovered DCIS on one side. Even a subsequent MRI didn't reveal the other problems. Only after two surgical biopsies did they have enough evidence of BC: DCIS, LDIS, Tubular BC, and other abnormal tissues, on both sides. One Dr. has suggested I may have developed the abnormal tissues due to all the mammorgrams I had almost yearly for twenty five years. No one I  know who has had BC had it discovered by mammogram, only by self-examination.
Posts.Title: My pink problem Melinda41 daffodil45

Posts.Content: Oct 30, 2010 10:07PM - edited Aug 20, 2013 03:03AM by orchidgal My first Pinktober, DX this April, and honestly, I've never felt good or even okay about the color pink associated with BC. My mother died of it, my friends died of it, and my clients have died of it. Seen, and been care taker to lots of end of life horror due to BC and other cancers & AIDS. So relieved to see there are other women out there, and here, who share my sentiments. I've been called a hero, survivor, herione, brave, smart, inspirational woman, etc. and while I appreciate the honor, don't feel like I'm all that. Life happens and you deal with it, including falling apart at first trying to figure out how to go about dealing with it. Was invited by a woman I know who had BC a few years ago to run a race or take a walk for BC earlier this month. Why? For whom? In two days it will be November, National Suicide Month. What color ribbon is that? My brother killed himself in March, six weeks before I got the DX with BC. I'll soon deal with Novembercide, and then be done with it come December 1! Do all of our tragedies and traumas now require colored ribbons to be officially ackowledged? Thanks for hearing me out!

Posts.Content: Jun 14, 2010 09:03PM orchidgal wrote: almagetty, hey it must be so good to fully shower again! how are you feeling? how many pain pills are you taking these days? do you have spasms re the TEs? my mind is racing on all this stuff, so happy you are moving through it well. jillyg & robin: also having 1st been DX w/ DCIS, further biopsies revealed more, and tomorrow I go for another biopsy type thing, and that will tell if it is underneath the nips. With dense breasts you can't be sure. My BS thinks there is infiltrating in there, too due to the multifocal & multi- centric presentation. Since it is early, it's good to take the time to be mentally & emotionally prepared, yet take care of business, so we can be part of the great statistics your doctor offered, free of disease! Well, finally some form to this crazy diagnosis. Visited the plastic surgeon today. Did I mention she's wonderful? and a real, human being? We were able to set up her schedule with the breast surgeon and hospital for July 22. Yeah. Not really. But it's good to know there's a point of departure from this anticipatory purgatory of waiting to find out when I get to go under and get rid of the several different types of early cancer that live in my breasts now. At least it will happen when they've both returned from vacation, and the appt. is the first one of the day, at 7 am. That means showing up there at 5 am. And being finished by probably midday. This gives me time to get my life a bit more organized and to also get serious about "training" for surgery.She took photos of my breast from every angle imaginable. So possibly she will create a reasonable facsimile out of what is left behind after the breast surgeon does her thing. Ordered a special front zip sports bra as recommended by plastic surgeon. Both my surgeons are young, smart, beautiful, and compassionate. What more can you ask for in a situation like this? Tomorrow I take the breast surgeon on a test run with this subareolar disk resection, and besides this procedure revealing what is under those nipples, and if they can be saved, it will also promote vascular growth that, come July 22, will have spread nicely to insure a better chance at blood supply to the skin remaining after this upcoming skin-saving, possibly nipple/areola saving mastectomy. Whew!

Posts.Content: Aug 6, 2010 09:24PM - edited Aug 7, 2010 01:59PM by orchidgal Hi Ladies, Good to hear from everyone. Getty, so glad you are taking a trip - yes, we all deserve one, and I hope we all get something to distract us from what we've been through in the next few months or so. Laurie, I'm glad your "old life" is coming back again and that your family harmony is bringing you happiness for everyone in your family. What you wrote really touched me as I also lost my mom to BC when I was 37. Took a leave of absence from UCLA when I was ready to graduate to do hospice with her, on my own, and she died in my arms. It was so hard to process that for about three years. We do say we're lucky, and we are, and yet it is true that we have suffered sorrows and losses and important to acknowledge that part of our experience and lives. My hope is that it helps me to develop into a more compassionate and thoughtful  and wise human being who can do more for others while I'm here. I do miss my breasts and feel strange having these plastic balloons in my chest feeling so much pressure, and being tired. These things will change as everything does, but its good to be present with our feelings as we float down the river of time, don't you think? Just had my first dream of my brother who died in March this morning, so putting the grieving on hold for the BC surgery worked, yet now that grieving work is back to be attended to as well. Grist for the mill, and am glad to be alive and well.  Hope you all have a nice weekend!

Posts.Content: Dec 15, 2010 06:15AM orchidgal wrote: I hear you on this one, and I go the way of Getty, say a silent prayer that they won't ever have to face what we've been through. It does amaze me sometimes when I tell them I am in the process of BC reconstruction, mostly people I've befriended this year who didn't know, but in the process of getting to closer, I decide to let them know, especially what with hospital dates, drugs, etc. that are hard to hide to some you have more frequent contact with. But I get a lot of responses like, "oh, my dog/cat has cancer, too" It really blows me away, but I sort of chuckle to myself, as I require all the positive, loving energy inside of me to continue to circulate and heal. Going into anger mode just makes me feel bad in so many way. This has been/continues to be an enormous lesson in compassion and loving kindness. I am a Buddhist, so these teachings have become so much more real to me in this, as I realized I had a choice, and going the "middle way" has brought deep insight, and heart opening. It is a very spiritual experience, and I'm so grateful. Also grateful for you gals here. Couldn't have gotten this far without you! As far as the exchange, Laurie, I'm one week out. They took my drains out and tape off today. I was crying in the office, I think out of sheer exhaustion, as I haven't been sleeping much, but also relief and grief, etc. from everything, and the realization that I lost my breasts. My new ones are beautiful! Am so lucky to have this wonderful and kind doctor who takes great pains to make them look gorgeous. I am sore & stiff, due to pocket work, and swollen on top. They don't project as the TEs did, but they are the perfect size for my petite frame. Will post photos as soon as some swelling diminishes. I put away the wedge pillow that I've been using for months,and find that I can sleep okay with several regular pillows. I think Getty worked out the sneaky side sleep technique. I prop up a pillow under my ribcage, and have my head pillows elevated so that the breast hangs free, sideways. I was told not to sleep on my side or stomach for at least six weeks, not to break a sweat, or let my heart rate go up over 90 for the next three weeks. And I must wear a bra 24/7. Have a couple of cotton sports bras which are fine. You'll be so happy to get those TEs out, it is like everyone says, night and day!! As for recovery, I have laid low for a week, and will continue to be easy and gentle with myself. But I have energy and am doing some walking, but gentle walking, not the power stuff I usually do. Hope this answers some of your questions. Feel free to ask anything else, since I'm the guinea pig of late :~) Wishing everyone a wonderful holiday, and Getty, have a blast on your cruise. You'll thaw out nicely! Will be with you in spirit, soak it up!! It will take you to another world and this will be forgotten temporarily. I'll bet you'll look great in your swim suit, too!  I actually bought a bikini the other day, something I had planned to do before all this stuff came down in March. I've given myself the gift of a personal retreat by renting a little place on the ocean in central California, Cayucos, a tiny, slow beach town that I love to visit. I'll be there for three days before Christmas and have some quiet uninterrupted time to reflect, pray and renew.  Yes, may 2011, the Year of the Rabbit, be kind and loving. The year of the Tiger has bared claws and teeth, yet if we survived it, as so many I know have had big challenges, we will be rewarded by the Rabbit/Cat....many happy returns everyone! xoxo Melissa

Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2010 10:22PM orchidgal wrote: ducki: thanks for making me laugh, over and over! I, too refuse to take tamox or any hormore therapy afterwards. osteoporosis runs in our family, plus my aunt just had a break down from using tamox after one year, fell down three times, got bruised, dizzy, weak, had to have help to stay with her. I respect the choice of any one who feels the need to take it, so may we all remain disease free, whatever the methods we choose. joystars: yay! you and your darling little baby are safe, and it's over now, you can move on without worries! glad you had such an easy time. it will take time to get used to the new chest, and I'm so happy your DH is there to give you deep love. getty: do as much research as possible. i see your dx is dcis stage 3. i was told that i needed no therapy afterwards, although the only onc I've seen recommended hormone therapy. the damage just isn't worth it to me, and if the surgery removed the bc, why take toxic drugs? It's certainly a personal issue, but my PCP supports me in refusing. I'll see another onc after surgery. one doc I went to for consultation said tamox. is a current "trend" BC treatment, and not a definitive preventative, but very dangerous. laurie: I took valium for my surg. excision, night before and morning of, and not for my more recent lumectomy, and the valium time was so much better. Posts.Content: Jul 7, 2010 09:15PM orchidgal wrote: Hi Ladies, I am all smiles reading your incredible posts! Very important information here! And much progress with everyone. Drains. My instructions are to not do much activity at all for the first two to three weeks, then start mild aerobics, if allowed. I'm glad you found out Liz what was making all that fluid flow! About the generics. Having been on this road for a while, earlier on I was taking Ambien to sleep. They gave me generic and it was horrible stuff, not at all like real Ambien. I took it back and made a declaration that it was junk, and they took it back and replaced it with real Ambien. At Walreens here in misty, cool Santa Monica. Yes, it has been lightly raining for the past three days. I love it, as it keeps things more quiet and people more subdued, but there are those who insist that July be SUNNY. Oh well.. Today I was at Walgreen's again,  getting my RXs for the big surgery July 22. I insisted on all name brands, and the pharmacist acted like I was bit of a problem as she had to look each of them up. Seems Big Pharma is in bed with Big Med Insurance Co. and they are setting everyone up to just take generics. The pharmacist said they "punish" anyone who orders name brand by charging huge amounts of money. I'm of the mind that I'd rather pay $100 for the real deal, because I'll only be on these drugs a short while and might as well have the ones that work properly and are effective. The young guy pharmacist I sometimes get there said wistfully that he wished he could afford name brand, that he'd get them, too. So I have ordered name brand Valium, Oxycontin plain, without aspirin, tylenol, or any other "filler" and then the antibiotic is also to be name brand. I must wait a week for the Oxycontin, but why not? it's true those generics have a lot of leeway to put only a % of the real stuff in there and fill it up with other junk the rest of the way. This must be a part of the decline of Western Civilization as we are getting to know it first hand. I'm sorry you got left in the lurch, Liz! and then got set straight by your Dr. so those drains will come out sooner than later. Good for you for having such a great workout routine! Glad you've got your drains gone, stlcardsfan - onward and upward! Laurie, sounds like you are being a very good patient and have a darling husband taking care of you. Glad you are doing so well and you two got a break to yourselves. MRDRN, sorry you are having those pains, I'll be following you with the SMB arm thing most likely. I know it will relieve soon, though, and hope you are trying some of the "cures" for constipation as offered here by others. The warm prune juice sounds like a winner. Think I'll pre-dose with stool softeners, and then take more magnesium than usual, as that relaxes the peristalsis pretty well. And then keep prune juice on hand. JBL10 sounds like you are doing very well, and repeating the mantra, BE, not, DO, for the time being. Great advice for a fast recovery. Am glad someone mentioned looking at their boob. I saw photos of a woman who had the expanders I'll have, low height, and they look pretty deformed for the whole time, as there is no upper pole, but the end result will be good I trust for all of us who have TES awaiting exchange. Oh, yes, that's another forum! Oh, my surgeon said it will be an eight hours surgery. Three for the BS to do the BMX & SNB, then the PS to do the recon w/ TEs for four to five hours. Cannot imagine what that will be like, but I'll be alseep, so guess I will never know except the aftemath. Hang in there, everyone, and sooner than later you will be enjoying some cocktails and guacamole with chips by the pool while I drink, my prune juice and sleep all day and night on a pile of pillows. So happy you are all doing so well!!!

Jeanne: I can so relate to missing your breasts, especially when the replacements feel like wires wrapped too tight, around and through. Was feeling that way today, kind of sad, and my TEs are pumped up to beyond capacity now, so feel like I have these Barbie boobs sticking out and up, a bit self-conscious, & skin really right, too. Fabric and any type of bra feels very uncomfortable, except for the Costco camisoles, but I have tags of skin on each side of my scars that look like alien double nipples if I don't cover them up, so am trying to wear the camisole, then something loose over it. What if we could take these out, and have a break, just for five minutes? ReneeW: Regret that your BMX experience wasn't easy for you - they shouldn't have let you go home so soon. Posts.Content: Jun 3, 2010 03:12AM - edited Jun 3, 2010 03:13AM by orchidgal Hi Ladies, This is my first post. I have a likely permanent yet currently tentative surgery date set for June 21: BMX, SNB x2, TEs. My DX is L. Breast: DCIS Multicentric,  R. Breast: ADH, DCIS, LCIS, Tubular C. Pathology is all good, that is, as good as you would want it to be. ER, PR + BRCA 1 & 2, Neg. Have already had Mammo & Ultra, bi-lat core needle biopsies, R. surgical excision biopsy, MRI. Now the surgeon I'm choosing wants to do an outpatient surgery before MX: a subareolar disc resection to determine whether the nipples can be saved or not before surgery. Has anyone ever heard of this? I will meet the PS she works with a lot and recommended on Monday. My brother died by suicide 6 wks. before my DX. He was my last relative, so it was a very difficult few weeks of meltdowns, sleepless nights. I'm feeling more positive and ready to move forward. Not sure who will be there to help me, but I do have friends. The hardest part for me is asking/accepting help as I am usually the one helping others. Deep gratitude for this website and to all of you who are posting here. I don't feel so alone  knowing we are all in this together.  Sending blessings and prayers to you all.

Posts.Content: Jun 23, 2010 05:12PM orchidgal wrote: Hi Joy, Welcome to our fantastic group. Having been DX w/ DCIS, then more biopsies revealed LDIS, tiny bit of tubular carcinoma, ADH, on both sides, multicentric/multifocal, I was finally convinced to do the seemingly radical BMX. Posts.Content: Jul 3, 2010 08:42PM - edited Jul 3, 2010 08:50PM by orchidgal Hi July Ladies, I haven't been posting lately, but am reading your posts. I was originally to have surgery in late June, and it got changed to July 22, so that's why I am still on the June Mastectomy, as well as the July Mastectomy forum I started. A foot in each month, so to speak! So I just got plain tired out after a bi-lat. lumpectomy I had on the 15th of June. Still very sore and a little wiped out, so don't have much to say right now, though I am with you in spirit and know you are leading the way that I will follow after July 22. Meltdowns interspersed with good days. Thanks for all of your info. And congrats on all the milestones and celebrations, and visits with friends and family you are having. I guess the worst part is anticipating the surgery, and I've been doing that for over two months now, and still three weeks to go - yikes! Was DX'd April 20! Am in the process of getting things ready at my apt. for post surgery. Got a body pillow, a soft, poly blanket for the hospital and then for home, and a friend who had BC gave me her two large size stretchy, soft cammies (I can step into them) with the drain bags and puffy fillers. next purchase is a wedge pillow to sleep on. I am also a side & stomach sleeper, so this will be an adjustment, for sure. Plus the American Cancer Society sent me two cute, little pillows for underneath each arm. And I have a couple lanyards from back stage passes at concerts ready to those blasted drains. Am single, 55, no kids, currently not in a "relationship," and all of my family members have passed away. I am fortunate to have good friends and a couple of neighbors who will take turns taking care of and helping me in the hospital and at home. Have never stayed over in a hospital, so am scared, yet building the courage to march right in there and get this over with. I was so enthusiastic on this June forum initially, but now emotionally & psychically feel rather burned out. Excuse me for not being more supportive right now. I do hold good thoughts and pray for each and every one of you as your healing process continues. I'm glad we have these monthly mastectomy groups, and know we will all get through this safely, soon, and heal well.  That is my wish for us all. melissa orchidgal

Posts.Content: Jul 10, 2010 01:27AM orchidgal wrote: Hi June Ladies, So interesting and at times humorous to read your posts. Thanks for the laughs! And am glad to hear you are all making your way through the healing parts, slowly yet surely. Wanted to say re TEs, I asked which ones my PS will be using and he said Siltex low heigth 7100s. I couldn't find them online, so I asked his assistant. She said they were brand new ones that have "tabs" to suture them down so they don't migrate! Re the green tea, you can buy a bottle of green tea extract with "concentrated polyphenols," and just squirt it into your mouth or in a glass of water or a cup of herbal tea. It is decaffienated, too! An excellent hi-dose anti-inflammatory bromelain supplement is by Karuna, called Bromezyme 2400, it is super potency. I'm taking about 6-9 a day. Also, Thorne buffered C, you can take as much as you can up to bowel tolerance. Thorne Medi-Clear is an anti-infammatory Super MultiVitamin MIneral Amino Acid & More powder you can buy online. Pronogynol is a proanthocyandins supplement made from grapefruit seed extract, standardized, for reduced infections and increased immunity. Oncoplex ES is a concenttrated broccoli seed extract. Curcumin is also a potent anti-cancer plant you can buy in capsules. BRM 4 has triple effect NK (killer cell) activity. Also, R-Lipoic or L-Lipoic Acid, & tocotrienols. Uzzi Reiss has a wonderful book called The Natural Superwoman that outlines this stuff and more. Just a few things to consider when putting together a natural yet potent program to prevent BC from coming back. And yes, organic everything and healthy oils, raw, organic, unfiltered olive is best, - no canola, safflower, soy oils, please. Now to sleep! Take care everyone!

LG: Sorry to hear of your infection. Sounds like the antibiotics are taking care of it. Glad you posted the Darvocet info. Saw that today. It makes me so mad that they allow so many dangerous drugs for us then only take them away years after so much damage has been done I remember my first breast biopsy in '97 for a cyst. They gave me Darvocet. I took one and felt so ill in my gut from it I threw the rest away and went cold turkey through the pain. Renee: that would upset me, too, to hear my PS get confused. But then they are doing so many surgeries all the time. Your surgery is just a few days before mine on the 7th, so keeping good thoughts for us. My PS said it will be a four hour surgery, so I've been taken aback these past few days thinking it was only gonna be two or so. But I know he will do a great job, and that's what counts. So sad to hear that your vacation got canceled. Getty: I'm so excited about your nipple, and can see you are in the honeymoon stage, checking to see if it still there. What a miracle of modern medicine that they can fully reconstruct our parts. Is your foam removed, yet? How do you camoflauge it in your clothes? Laurie: I"m so GLAD you brought up this mindlessness thing. I have it too, and have been wondering why as I'm usually pretty sharp, and have put myself on a regime many years ago for mental clarity with diet, exercise & supplements, smart nutrients. Now I feel like I am partially senile! Renee, I have the same thing like forgetting the name of a common object, or someone's name. Have two cooking classes scheduled for the new year, so hope I don't blow it in front of my students! I  agree with Getty that all the stress, meds, and anesthesia we've been subjected to takes its toll, and want to believe that in a year or less our minds will clear up. Having chemo, rads, or post surgery hormone therpay only adds to this, so hope you find the right thing to do for those hot flashes, Renee. Friends keep reminding me that gen. anesthesia really gets our mind numbed out for a while. I figure since I've had three surgeries while being under, not counting that horribly painful stereotactic core needle biopsy, that so far in the last  seven months I've been under general anesthetic for at least ten hours. In a couple of weeks there will before more hours to add to that. I guess as strong as these drugs are, (hello - Morphine!) plus the stress on so many levels we aren't even aware of all adds up to having brain freeze. LG: I agree that the Valium does do a big number on our brains, although it is sort of necessary going through recon. Yesterday I went to pick up my surgery meds at the pharmacy, and didn't realize they'd also called in for Valium for me. I bought it, then saw when I got home that I still have a lot, and since I get name brand they were $100. The pharmacy wouldn't take them back, so I have some very expensive pills that I won't be taking, and attribute this to my brain being so numb. Normally I would be on top of it for something like this. My plan is to do a lot more aerobic exercise, hiking up hills is my fav, and maybe that will renew the blood flow and promote better circulation, especially after all these hours laying around and in bed! Let me know if anyone has anhymore ideas on this. Sorry you guys are experiencing this, too, yet glad I'm not alone!

Posts.Content: Nov 23, 2010 04:29AM orchidgal wrote: Hi, Had my BMX in July and found that a 30 degree wedge pillow has been perfect - I'm still sleeping on it and will use it again after my #2 recon surgery coming up in two weeks when I get implants. Also used my other pillows to support arms, plus a body pillow for my legs to go over so your posture is comfortable being elevated at your upper body. It is a cozy nest and I still sleep that way. The American Cancer Society sent me two little mastectomy pillows to put under my arms - they were a god send, especially to use when in the car under the seatbelt. Didn't have any trouble expressing the drains. I just put my laptop on a pillow on my lap, but slept alot in the beginning so didn't use it that much. Also, straws to drink from are good. I splurged and ordered glass drinking straws. I had fresh juices diluted 50% with water, like apple pomegranate. Also got Netflix, but didn't read very much. You'll be sleeping alot. The note pad right near your bed is essential. I turned the caps of my pill bottles around the other way so they were no longer child proff, then wrote the initial on the inside of the cap with a black permanent parker, I for ibuprofen, V for valium, etc. That helped alot. I had a drain cami, but never wore it, Found that a lanyard worked best for me, and didnt need a stool for the shower, either. I wore the bra they put on me in the hospital. Having a couple of loose tops will be good. I usually wore stretchy work out pants each day. As for hair washing, washed just before I went in and braided it as it is long, so it wouldn't get tangled up. A week later I had it washed at a local salon. I dried it myself. They only charged me $8 becasue they have a special for BC patients. I didn't know until I asked, so you might ask around. It made it so much easier. The next week I washed it myself. One more thing that was nice that was suggested on this site is a very soft synthetic throw to take to the hospital. I loved the way it felt and also when I got home used it all the time and didn't get under the covers as I needed to move aorund easier in and out of bed. Your skin will be extra senstivie so soft fabrics are really good. All the best, I know you will get through it and will be so much happier when you are BC free. Best, Melissa

Posts.Content: Jun 30, 2010 08:08PM orchidgal wrote: Ducki: Excuse me not getting you on here until now. Have been out of it from my last surgery, the bi-lumpectomy on the 15th. Gen Anesthesia did me in! Sending healing vibes your way, and wishes that you have a safe and smooth surgery to wake up peacefully and rest well. You're the leader of the July Ladies, so get back to us when you are feeling up to it and let us know how it feels to be DONE! ann42: welcome aboard, and wishing you a good month as we navigate the territory and get across the finish line. I'm sad that you are revisiting BC, and glad you have your family and kids to be there for you. tory: Welcome, and sad to meet you under these circumstances, yet happy you've joined our group. The PS I'm going with uses crescent shaped TES, as I wanted to avoid the protruding upper pole, and have small breasts. Also, he fills in the dent left by SNB, and removes the fat pad in front of the underarms. He also doesn't cut the pecs, yet does do a neurectomy on them so they are "quiet" as they tend to "jump" a lot. Also takes more time between surgeries to avoid capsular contraction, and to let implants settle well before nip recon. Thanks for mentioning massage. Am wondering when it is okay to start getting the scars left from SNB & drains massaged. Does anyone know? I will ask to see the PT before surgery and ask and let everyone know if I get any info. Rose: Good for you to be in "training" for your surgery. I am too, and being a nutritional consultant, am maybe a bit overzealous, but it does work! Eating lots of veggies gives your body great immunity against infection, eliminating sugar & refined & gluten containing foods does this as well as reduce inflammation. Also quitting stimulants and alcohol helps your body require less anesthesia. I aim for 40-60 grams of protein a day. Also, I just bought a hard foam roller to lie on vertically, and do very slow snow angels to stretch out the pecs. You can also stretch them by placing your hand around back of you flat on the wall, then pulling you opposite shoulder back, and do both sides. A PT taught me this. Re SNB Dye: I asked my BS and she said she does it all after you are under. I'm sad to hear of anyone suffering needlessly with this procedure. Not sure why they differ so. I heard one reason is the equipment is in another room. I think it is all in the OR at my hospital. Clarity: I hope you are now resting peacefully, healing well, and feeling so good to be DONE! Hi DiDel: Thanks for injecting us with your positive spirit and kind words. It is so appreciated to be cheered on by those who have already gone through it. What I keep hearing over and over is the worst part is the anticipation (and the DRAINS) but I hope to be able to joke at least some of the time about the drains...DiDel, you can be our JULY Ladies mascot! zenith: Glad you were pro-active in asking for lidocaine and will spare yourself the shock. Many of us were taught as females not to speak up yet having BC demands it! Since I'm the List Lady, everybody let me know what you want put up or changed, and I'll take care of it.  Melissa / orchidgal

Posts.Content: Jul 10, 2010 04:35PM orchidgal wrote: Okay, here's what happened today. The oncological pharmacist at the Oncology Group I went to earlier in my DX gave me a recommendation letter from their oncologist to use medical marijuana. I decide to go to the MMJ pharmacy today to check it out. They registered me, but couldn't complete it, since it is Saturday, the doctor is out and didn't answer her page. So I didn't purchase any medications. But the young kid behind the counter was trying to help me figure out what to get for post-surgery. The onc. pharm said to use "multiple modalites" and cycle the narcs, MMJ, muscle relaxers and anti-inflammatories. The kid asked when my surgery was and I told him when and that it would be an eight hour operation. He said, "Oh, something wonderful and fun, then?" and I just looked at him and asked if he thought having a double amputation was great and fun. He didn't get it. I think he's been sampling the goods too much! Is anyone else planning on using or using MMJ? I hadn't planned on it, but they offered it to me. Seems like a good idea to try as suggested, the drinkable teas, and the edible goodies like the chocolates, cookies, etc. a a way to taper off narcs. They also had extra "un-virgin" olive oil!

Let us know how you're doing when you feel ready to. Sending good healing vibes your way - (((HUGS))) tory & kim11: Your big day is tomorrow, and I hope you are winding down and calmly happy that you will be DONE! sooner than you'll know it. Keep your spirits up and it will be over and you will be DONE! I'm right behind you, so your DONE will be a little delayed. My hospital says they are state of the art wired with wi-fi, so will have my friend bring my laptop, and if I can see through the morphine haze, write up all of our (finally) DONES! That is, up to the 22nd, we still have the caboose pulling up the rear! Yo ladies back there! We're with ya! Elizabeth, Torigirl, nkrun, & onward we love you, too. Psalms91: Welcome. Peace is where you find it - a hot bath with candles, a quiet walk in the cool evening, praying and connecting with your loved ones who have passed, asking them for support and prayers,  knowing that your angels, guardians, and special friends are all sending prayers, best wishes, kind thoughts, love, and support for you to get on the other side of this. Breath deeply and slowly and let out any fear, and let in the warm sunshine, let it wash over you and wash away any emotions or thoughts that may be knocking around in there. Feel yourself protected in the hand of God, because you are. So be it. LOVE & HUGS HEALING & GRACE to you all...... Melissa aka orchidgal

Posts.Content: Jun 22, 2010 04:27PM orchidgal wrote: Debra - It is so scary to get a diagnosis. it's natural to feel panicked, shocked, & disbelief. What is your DX? - short for: "diagnosis" We are not doctors, but I , too have small breasts and have DCIS throughout one, and similar things in the other. I saw three breast surgeons and they all said I have to have mastoctomies as the breast would be deformed otherwise. keep copies of all tests, pathology reports, etc. Take them to your all your doctors appts. Chemo is only used for invasive cancers, so perhaps you have early stage?  Have faith that you will have treament to get rid of the cancer and keep researching, and go to different doctors for opinions if you aren't sure what one doctor tells you. Melissa

Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2010 05:37PM orchidgal wrote: ReginaA: yes, we will be supporting one another and we also share info, as we all do our own types of research. So many have been such great help to me so far. BC is a little like treasure hunting in a mine field! Scrabblelady: sometimes I've got to stop reading as it is TMI - too much info - yet the right time and right amounts have been so good for me to feel connected to those who are in the same boat. Very grateful for these forums. Hoping the June ladies will visit us here, too. They are a great bunch of women, as are you all. We will get through this! in_cognito: yay! you got bumped up - I put your new date on the list. Hope it sticks this time! Will miss sharing July 22nd with you, though ;~(             But happy you get to go earlier...  sespebadger: not sure why you must have rads after MX. Because you are Stage 3a w/ nodes?  So much I don't know about BC after all my research... it does feel so sad to lose these breasts, although I will keep the outside, sans nipples, still it is a shock. I wake up everyday and look at them in the mirror, touch them and say, good-bye, thanks for the memories. Wish I had a boyfriend now who would help me say good-bye.;~) Clarity04: Thoughts and prayers to you as you prepare for your surgery - we will all be thinking of you and looking forward to our first post from you when you can write to us and tell us what the "other side" is like. Rose; I feel for you being torn between your job and the "endless homework" of having been DX w/ BC. How much time off will you be able to take? Are you getting recon, too?

Posts.Content: Jul 5, 2010 11:38AM orchidgal wrote: lymphtherapist: I'm sorry you are feeling so out of it. Understandably, so! Where do you live, Arizona? Good you are resting up, and hope you let go of thinking about the weight/wait. You'll probably lose it after surgery if you eat lots of soup. Sounds like a good choice to not have SNB. I'm choosing to have it on both sides as they found a small amount of tubular BC on one side, so although not likely to be invasive, it is stage one. The other side is so dense with DCIS that it will be done too. I work out with weights and am very healthy, so keeping a good thought for not having any complications from the surgery. My surgeon said she hasn't had one patient get LE from her SNBs. I hope you find a way to calm your mind. Been told that taking a valium the night before then the day of surgery helps a lot ;~) too. BIG HUGS and lots of prayers for a safe surgery and calm awakening tomorrow in recovery! We'll be waiting to hear from you when you are DONE - yay! I'm glad you're not entirely losing your breasts! Melissa

Posts.Content: Jul 10, 2010 02:56AM orchidgal wrote: Welcome New Ladies, sorry you are joining us this way, but so glad to have you on board - the more, the mellower! DONE Ladies: wow, you have come back so fast to tell us what your experience is like. So Happy to hear you are doing well.scrabblelady, calamtykel, clarity, zenith, regina, ann, photobug, catwood, lymphtherapist: you are all healing well it sounds like, managing pain, and sharing your good vibes with us, so thank you. zenith, I'm sorry about your node DX. ladyblevins, hope you are feeling as well as can be. ducki, glad you are coming along so well.  For those of you coming up, the count down is so hard sometimes! sespebadger, shawn, debpurple, youngmom, you're next. Prayers for a peaceful and distracted weekend hope you get a chance to unwind and laugh a bit. Kim, and all, I've been freaking out after having hit such a nice calm a week or so earlier.I don't think it is at all self-absorbed or narcissistic to mourn the loss, or feel bad, or cheated about losing your breasts. Whether or not they "define" you, or whether they are large, small, whatever, they are a part of you, and I too am sad to hear of you younger gals as I am 55, and have enjoyed my breasts for many years, but still feel young, and so do my breasts, they look great, and feel great. So sorry you are leaving them behind so soon in life. My hope is that they can rebuild some bionic ones in the near future that we can trade out for the silicon or whatever your choice may be. So this surgery & aftermath/healing/recon. process is a reckoning. With the DCIS, I also have gone round and round on that one, and they keep saying the only treatment to be sure is BMX, as I have it in both sides. You'd think there would be something they could do to treat Stage 0 BC without taking them away! We are fortunate to have such great health care at hand, and to have this forum. If not for this forum I would be so lost in this all. No matter how friends might want to be supportive, they cannot understand what it is like to have to go through this unless they've had it themselves. Even then, some are so stoic, they don't want to talk about it or express emotions. The most healthy way is to express it, let it out, say your truth and be heard, and accepted. We are doing this here. Thanks to you all for being here everyone, even those who don't ever reveal themselves. It is truly amazing how many July Ladies are appearing every day.

Posts.Content: Jul 12, 2010 01:18AM - edited Jul 12, 2010 01:23AM by orchidgal Hi Ladies, Thinking and praying for those of you who are going got to have surgery tomorrow: sespebadger, debpurple & youngmom. May you find peace knowing your BC will be removed, and wake up in recovery with a smile, rest well, and come home soon. Shawn, Mary & sunnydaze, you're coming up this week, too, so BIG HUGS to all of you - sending (((good vibes))) your way. I know you'll do fine and come back to report. Can't wait to write a big DONE after all of your names! Regina, when I was in Arkansas in March I noticed they called MJ a "narcotic" on the news.So strange to see how much laws and attitudes vary from state to state, region to region! Hope you have your "personal massager" well hidden from the morality police...I would have corrected the PS on the spot, although I realize how vulnerable we all feel sitting there in a robe while they are fully dressed. They have no idea! A few people have suggested to me it's my chance to "go big" as I am small. This DX continues to teach me to cultivate patience and compassion everyday, what a spiritual boot camp BC can be. sespebadger: I have that booklet and a lot of others that ACS sent to me, along with two cute little pillows with tags on the cases, "Made with Love by the Women of the Eastern Star" that are to use under my arms after the BMX. Have been trying to make appts with the phys. therapy office and they are so booked they can only say they'll try to see me beforehand. I did speak with her and she said the most important thing is to not do any weight bearing at all in the beginning, or that could cause cording and scarring that are hard to make gone. She said the gently raising the arms to the sides, finger walking up walls, and arms out to front are okay, but no pushing. I'm sad to hear of your dad. My dad died three years ago, July 14, and we were very close. He was a veteran of Wll, Korea & Viet Nam, a large, strongman and it was so sad to see him get smaller and in pain. Am so happy he opened up to you. My dad's last words to me were "I love you." Am glad you had as much time as possible with him.  My prayers and condolences are with you and your family. May your memories bring you warmth and consolation. Zenith, I'm so sorry to hear of your DX and impending chemo. I hope you do what sespebadger suggests and research so you can go into this phase of your treatment empowered and able to ask the right questions and feel like you are also a partner in the process. Hope you get released from hospital soon, and that your DH is there by your side until then to care for you. My friend said when he was in for a heart attack in the ICU that the nurse was ignoring him, so he used his cell phone to call the hospital, asked for the ICU, and got his nurse on the phone, and said please come in here. I'm looking at you right now! nkrun: wow, I'm surprised you have a surgery date and yet not sure what they will do. Am sheepish to admit I'm so glad there is someone to go after me. I was last of the June Ladies, then got changed to last of July, until you showed up! I was DX w/ DCIS on R at first, after a bi-lat. core needle biopsy, then had a surg. excision on one side that revealed more  on L, ADH, DCIS, LCIS, tubular carcinoma. Then another surgeon did a sub-areolar disk resection to see if the nipples could be saved, not. So now that all the avenues have been exhausted I'm having the BMX. Saw three different BSs & four PSs. With MX you ususally do not have to do rads or chemo, with lumpectomy, oftentimes they want you to do rads and/or chemo. If you have damaged skin from rads, then later require an MX, that skin is hard to work with if you also want recon. I hope you find out more. It's too bad your onc was out of line with you asking about MMJ. And your son is being a California boy, and I would be upset, although I did the same things at his age. And you would not be a hyprocrite to join him, although he probalby has no reason to have it, but at least he is quasi-legal now. Haven't smoke for ages, but I think when I get the paperwork finalized and can buy something, some of these "edibles" and "drinkables"  will be good. Heard about it from some little old ladies in a therpay group that it worked well for them. The pain from recon apparently merits "multiple modalities," as the onc. pharmacist told me. She's the one who suggested she get a letter for me so I can get it. I, too have led a very healthy, active life, and am seeing this eight hour surgery coming up as a challenge. Am in "training," exercising everyday, and eating an anti-inflammation diet w/ lots of protein, taking lots of supplements and listening to guided visualizations everyday, as well. You don't have to be perfect forever, but it seems that leading up to and healing after such surgery is a good time to be really, really good. Then practice moderation with a very healthy baseline later, and I'm sure you'll be fine.

Posts.Content: Jul 18, 2010 10:28PM orchidgal wrote: Peppercook & Katherine Naomi: Sending prayers and special healing thoughts and vibes to you as you prepare for surgery tomorrow. May you wake up in recovery at peace knowing you are DONE! Mary, your post made me feel so much better. I read it to a friend and we both laughed, you have a great attitude! I'm right behind you! Calamtykel & sunnydaze, glad you are doing so well so soon and enoying the lightness in your bodies. There's a plus side to everything. zenith: sad to hear of your DX, and know you wil get through it as you have so far, with courage and intelligence. Doing the research makes a world of difference in your experience. Ann & Rose - thanks for your kind & encouraging words. MRDRN: nice to hear from you - thanks for popping in to say hi and offer some support! Ducki: regret you still have your drains in, surprised you got a fill still with drains, haven't heard of that yet. I know you'll come out fine, just hang in there, gal. stlcrdsfan: thanks for checking in with us. Your tips are appreciated! I did get that drain cami from a friend who was given two in the hospital so will try to use them. Not sure what to do with drains at night as I always sleep nude, but maybe will have to sleep with something to hold them together, have a couple of lanyards. So glad to hear form you. I'm getting ready for  my surgery this Thursday, at last, having been DX'd in April! It seems like the journey to BMX w/ TEs has been so very long and interesting, lots of ups and downs, many doctors, meltdowns, a couple fender benders, four parking tickets, a couple of surgeries, and connecting with so many friends and strangers who are there for me - finally, now, I feel at peace! Gratitude for all of you on these boards for your love & support!

You are all so beautiful and I feel so blessed to have stumbled upon this place. Will write back as soon as possible and then, I too, will be DONE!! Yay, thanks for all the encouragement and support ladies, I love you! Hang in there, the journey just keeps getting more interesting. xox Melissa aka orchidgal

Posts.Content: Jun 23, 2010 07:01PM orchidgal wrote: Welcome in_cognito! Sorry we have to meet like this. I got your PM and will answer soon. We might have our surgeries on the same date - surgery twins! sespebadge: I love your name! And also love hiking the wilderness trails around here. Hope you get back on the trails soon. Ditto in_cognito's advice. I had hospice care when my mother was dying of BC in '92. I did it alone, with a little help from a couple of her friends, burt hospice set me up with everything I needed and I had a 24 hr. nurse to call whenever I wanted to. My mom did not want to go back to the hospital and she died peacefully at home. It is so much more sane and humane. Best of luck with it all.

Posts.Content: Jul 24, 2010 06:32PM orchidgal wrote: Hi July Gals, Guess what? I am done!! Yay!! And it was a piece of cake, actually seems like a cosmic journey. The doctor are so wonderful, as are the nurses and the staff, and the hospital is like a boutique hotel! Woke up in recovery with no nausea, but the nurses were changing shifts and although she set up my pain pump, forgot to give me the button, so I had a bit of intensity lasting a small while being transferred to my bed in my room. It was so dreamy being on that morphine, and now I am on oral meds. I choose "perconone" which has no fluff or filler, just oxycodone, and not salicylic acid or tylenol, just pure, plain, synthetic morphine, plus valium, the great muscle relaxer. The nurse are dolls, yet they seem to leave it up to me to ask for the pain drugs so sometimes I fall alseep and wake up with an owie, sore like I did one thousand push ups,nothing unmanageable. I'm so surprised at how good I feel and all my guests say I look great and have good color, etc. I can see some breast mounds, too. Doc said he filled them 50 %. Have a tight bra on, and will see the PS Tuesday to check up on that. Get the path report Thursday at the BS office. She told my friend that the nodes taken, I think 2 on each side, seemed good and pliable, soft. Hope for the best there.  Thank you for all of your loving and kind words, well wishes and encouragement. You're all right - this was the easiest part so far! Having never been in the hospital it is actually fun and delightful in some ways - large plasma TV, not bad food, either. A nurse gave me a little shower, sponge bath and & foot massage today. Am rambling as these drugs are wont to make one do, so will close now wishing you all the best. Without this board I would have felt so lost! (((BIG HUGS))) to ALL. xoxox orchidgal
Posts.Title: JULY MASTECTOMY orchidgal rosesrx

Posts.Content: Jul 30, 2010 02:37AM orchidgal wrote: Dear All, Thinking of you all lots and sending prayers and smiles. I'm doing fine, just resting a lot and having various friends taking care of me and dropping by to visit (most of the time I forget they came by!) seems like it takes up so much time! I miss hanging out with you gals, my bc.org pals, discussing the nitty gritty of it all. I shall return and be more involved. Please send me a PM if someow I missed your mention of having finished your surgery, or you want me to post you here having already had surgery in July,  so I can write you in as DONE!. Got my path report today and I am 0/4, so absolutley cancer free. So relieved. Sending lots of love and letting you know I am doing fine, it just seems to take so much time answering the phone, eating meals, measuring drain fluids, charting meds, dr. appts., Thank goodness my dear friend who was here from SF made up lots of healthy, tasty food that is at hand in fridge & freezer. I trust that the days and nights will open up when I have all that time some of you seem to have to watch tv, etc. Do take care and know my thoughts and prayers are with you. Can't wait to compare notes on all this "after surgery" stuff. So far I am doing well. I guess since the TEs are sewn onto my chest wall they don't move around, so minimal pain. They are already filled 50% and look great - It's hard to believe it, but true. And they say the real thing will be incredible - bring it on, baby! Great range of motion, but am laying low, not exercising except for small amounts of walking around the apt doing little things, and taking short slow walks. Seriously Constipated! so it looks like it's gonna take the big guns - already tried lots of stool softener & magnesium caps - now it will have to be COLACE - to get things moving. Hope you are all doing as well as can be expected and then some. Much love & big hugs, Melissa aka orchidgal

Posts.Content: Jun 13, 2010 11:41PM orchidgal wrote: Welcome photobug & eileen1955. I was also born in 1955, so we are 55 years old now. I also think it is good to have the surgery after the drs. return from vacation. That's why I passed on the 6/29 date they offered me because the PS was leaving for a trip in 7/1 and then the BS leaving on 7/5, so that means the first week they'd both be gone for three days. Posts.Content: Jun 14, 2010 02:52PM orchidgal wrote: Well, finally some form to this crazy diagnosis. Visited the plastic surgeon today. Did I mention she's wonderful? and a real, human being? We were able to set up her schedule with the breast surgeon and hospital for July 22. Yeah. Not really. But it's good to know there's a point of departure from this anticipatory purgatory of waiting to find out when I get to go under and get rid of the several different types of early cancer that live in my breasts now. At least it will happen when they've both returned from vacation, and the appt. is the first one of the day, at 7 am. That means showing up there at 5 am. And being finished by probably midday. This gives me time to get my life a bit more organized and to also get serious about "training" for surgery.She took photos of my breast from every angle imaginable. So possibly she will create a reasonable facsimile out of what is left behind after the breast surgeon does her thing. Ordered a special front zip sports bra as recommended by plastic surgeon. Both my surgeons are young, smart, beautiful, and compassionate. What more can you ask for in a situation like this? Tomorrow I take the breast surgeon on a test run with this subareolar disk resection, and besides this procedure revealing what is under those nipples, and if they can be saved, it will also promote vascular growth that, come July 22, will have spread nicely to insure a better chance at blood supply to the skin remaining after this upcoming skin-saving, possibly nipple/areola saving mastectomy. Whew!

Posts.Content: Jul 20, 2010 10:33AM orchidgal wrote: Elizabeth: Welcome to our July group. Nice to meet you, sad under these conditions. We're all in it together and God Bless this forum where we can let it all hang out and support one another! You're right after me, and so I'll keep the seat warm for you! I know you'll get through it as so many others have. One gal on here said that her pastor told her to just keep sight of what's right in front of you. It helps me to do that, stay focused, keep it moving and don't get hung up anywhere, and not expect to solve everything at once. Baby steps. I've posted your data. calamtykel: wow, what a story! sorry you got the wrong drugs! what do you use instead of morphine? the last anesthesia I had was for a double lumpectomy in June and didn't feel okay waking up, but never threw up, just felt cranky and fuzzy. other times felt great. Am sure they use a different cocktail per the occasion. Maybe I'll get lucky and get a "margarita" like you did! love the time warp/no memory part, though. my friend said she would push the pain pump for me when I'm sleeping! Rose: Glad you ddi fine coming out of it. To each their own, huh? My arrival time to check in is 5 am - surgery commences at 7 am, & goes on for about 8 hours. I passed up another date as it started at 2:30,and I feel better having them first thing in the morning fresh. . . Anyone want to wager on how many more women will join us before the month closes out??

Posts.Content: Aug 5, 2010 12:40AM orchidgal wrote: Shawn, so glad to hear your great news. Yay! Wanted to touch in as I've been out of touch lately. Now thirteen days out of surgery, and still have bursts of energy, then get tired soon after doing a few things. Not driving yet as still on meds, but trying to get off meds. It hurts though, so that is the "rub" huh? Have TEs, and  not twitching, as my PS did a neurectomy of the pecotralis major, actually he severed three or so on each side, but still feel the "iron bra that is too tight" feeling and aches and pains that come and go. Had a pre-op PT eval. and am waiting for the PS to get back from vacation to sign me on to actually go get the PT. Meanwhile tomorrow will get a lymphatic massage that apparently comes with the surgery, one free one, that is. The two drains are out, thankfully. Am not feeling weeping, but have had friends staying all this time, taking turns driving me and cooking, etc, so little alone time which I'm starting to miss, but sure grateful for the  friends helping me.When the friend who is here now leaves Sunday then I will be on my own and I plan to be off the meds that prevent driving so I can be self-sufficient again. Finding that a three hour nap in the afternoon does wonders. Don't have a recliner, but created one in my bed with a body pillow on one side, and a wedge, then lots of other pillows. Being a tummy sleeper it's actually not bad, and no back ache. I have good range of movement but not sure if I should be doing any exercises now or not. I can easily run my fingers all the way up the wall and hold my arms out straight forward and out to the sides. Takes effort to stand up straight and pull shoulders back. Had hair washed at a salon a week ago, now I can do it myself tomorrow maybe in the shower. Hope you guys are hanging in there. It seems that maybe the two or three week let down feelings may be a combo of people thinking you're okay now and the attention becoming less, also feeling more pain as you are taking less drugs and the numbness i wearing off. Not to mention the reality that your breasts are gone and in their place area  couple of rock hard plastic bags! I feel grateful to be able to have recon, so not complaining, but the reality is setting in and I find myself feeling a bit strange walking around in public holding my chest up but not "leading" with nipples, as they are gone. Am not in a relationship, so don't know what that would be like to introduce a mate to the new situation, or in the future when I do have a boyfriend again,but that is not really something I'm thinking of these days. Want to get stretched and strong again and look forward to the exchange which will be for me around December. Not allowed to do exercise until three weeks, then it's light aerobic only, then at around six weeks back to regular exercise - seems like forever! Sending love & hugs to all. orchidgal, ~Melissa
